On the questions of dogma or general discipline which divided the East and the West, it was an understood thing that the Pope had the right to speak in the name of all the Western Churches. The Pope's decretals had the same legal force as the decisions of councils, and were inserted under the same category in the collection of canons. No spot in the West was more sacred, and no moral or religious authority could be compared to that of the priest who ministered at those illustrious shrines.
